content: If there are no objections, I'd like to add cover art to this puzzle.
We have spoken about the changes to make by message, and they're made. The different errors in the statement are fixed. All seems ok ! Let's go !

Thank you for your remarks.
I added a hint (with a link to the Sprague-Grundy theorem).
I modified the difficulty to medium.

Your statement says:
1 ≤ rows ≤ 35

But for the test case "More rows" the number of rows is more than 35.

JBM beat me. ^^

I do not have much to say, except that this puzzle is not balanced. On the one hand, all people who have a minimum of knowledge about game theory (Like a lot of CodinGamer who play to the multis/contests.) can easily find the solution (Or already know it). And on the other hand, for a beginer, yes, it's very hard (If possible).

But your graphical representation of this game is cool. ^^

Torn.

* This is a near-duplicate.
* But it brings graphics.
* It's not very hard at all if you know (sorry, I'm biased)
* Is it even considered findable if you don't? That does restrict the target audience a lot.

Side notes:
The columns variable isn't needed. (though its presence can be justified, don't read this as a deletion request)
The 0- or 1-indexing is not clear enough.
This is a slightly simpler (non-misere) version of https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/misere-nim with a visualization. Not very original, but why not after all?

I explain a little this contribution : 
It's a very hard challenge (I think) to find the winning strategy but the difficulty is not algorithmic (the strategy is equivalent to a easy puzzle).
So I propose to the community first without hint but I can add hints to transform it in an easier puzzle.

What about turning it into a reverse puzzle like https://www.codingame.com/multiplayer/optimization/codingame-sponsored-contest ? (that is, almost no rules, and no spoiling tag)

This way, you have a very hard puzzle like Nintendo and the other puzzle about nim becomes a hint (so no worry about redundancy).

Typos: "a game that ha[ve/s]", "a boss who know[/s]", "each player ha[ve/s]", "Each player play[/s]", "You [reach/manage] to block".
You could also explicitly mention (e.g. along with "You always begin.") that you always start on a winning position (I know it's implicit, yet to avoid confusion...).
